case_name: Inspector v. Chittapore Stone Quarrying Company Pvt. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 40 of 1968

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION10N Civil Appeal No. 40 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1860 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1860 of 1965

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1860 of 1965. H. Dhebar, for the appellant. Srinivasamurthy and Naunit Lal, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant Inspector initiated proceedings against respondent No. 1 in the court of Munsif Magistrate, Chittapur for breach of Minimum Wages Act provisions

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Inspector was of the view that respondent number Chittapore Stone quarrying Company  Pvt.  Ltd., Chittapurwhich was quarrying a variety of stone called Shahabad Stone in Chittapur, District Gulbarga, was engaged in the activity of stone breaking and stone crushing, and since respondent number 1 was in breach of some of the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 and the rules made thereunder he adopted proceedings to enforce the provisions in the companyrt of the Munsif Magistrate, Chittapur, respondent number 3.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 is Chittapore Stone Quarrying Company Pvt. Ltd., Chittapur, District Gulbarga

anchor.surface_text: respondent number Chittapore Stone quarrying Company  Pvt.  Ltd., Chittapurwhich was quarrying a variety of stone called Shahabad Stone in Chittapur, District Gulbarga, was engaged in the activity of stone breaking and stone crushing,

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was quarrying Shahabad Stone in Chittapur, District Gulbarga

anchor.surface_text: Chittapurwhich was quarrying a variety of stone called Shahabad Stone in Chittapur, District Gulbarga, was engaged in the activity of stone breaking and stone crushing, and since respondent number 1 was in breach of some of the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948

facts.text: Notification issued by Appropriate Government fixing minimum wages for stone breaking or stone crushing in Gulbarga District under Minimum Wages Act, 1948

anchor.surface_text: whether quarrying of Shahabad stone is an activity which companyld be properly described as stone breaking or stone crushing mentioned in the Schedule to The Minimum Wages, Act, 1949. By numberification issued by the Appropriate Government under the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 minimum wages were fixed for those employed in stone breaking or stone crushing in Gulbarga District.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed Writ Petition No. 1860 of 1965 in Mysore High Court to quash the proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number 1 thereupon filed a writ petition for quashing the proceedings  Writ Petition No. 1860 of 1965  in the Mysore High Court alleging, inter alia, that the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act did number apply to the particular activity in which it was engaged because, in itsubmission, the activity was number one of stone breaking or stone-crushing but of mining limsestone slabs.

facts.text: Mysore High Court quashed the proceedings before Munsif Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the process of removing Shahabad stone involved breaking and crushing but it was also of the view that what was broken or crushed was number really stone but a substance which very nearly approximated to a mineral. In that view it quashed the proceedings before the Munsif Magistrate.

facts.text: Shahabad stone quarrying involves removing earth over limestone layers by manual labour, removing overburden of thick limestone layers, baring thin limestone layers and cutting them into regular sizes

anchor.surface_text: The activity in which respondent number 1 is engaged is described as follows The earth which varies in depth from place to place over the limestone layers is removed by manual labour. This work of removing the soil is known as earth-work. The thin limestone layersfrom which the flooring stones are cut into regular sizes and which is the, main object of mining by us are reached after removing some thick layer of limestone over these thin layers.

facts.text: No stone breaking or stone crushing operations are carried on in respondent No. 1's mines

anchor.surface_text: The removal of the overburden of earth and thick layers of lime-- stone is incidental to the mining operations companyducted by us. The main operation of our mining is to bare open the thin layers of limestone and cut them into regular sizes. It is submitted that numberstone breaking or stone crushing operations are carried on in our mines.

facts.text: Shahabad stone is a variety of limestone used for flooring stones cut into regular sizes

anchor.surface_text: The thin limestone layersfrom which the flooring stones are cut into regular sizes and which is the, main object of mining by us are reached after removing some thick layer of limestone over these thin layers. The removal of the overburden of earth and thick layers of lime-- stone is incidental to the mining operations

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate granted by Mysore High Court

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Mysore raises an interesting point as to whether quarrying of Shahabad stone is an activity which companyld be properly described as stone breaking or stone crushing mentioned in the Schedule to The Minimum Wages, Act, 1949.

facts.text: Item 8 in Part I of Schedule to Minimum Wages Act, 1948 refers to employment in stone breaking or stone crushing

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 g  defines scheduled employment as an employment specified in the Schedule, or any process or branch of work forming part of such employment. The Schedule has two parts and item number 8 in part number 1 refers to employment in stone breaking or stone crushing.

facts.text: Notification fixing minimum wages for stone-breaking or stone-crushing in operation in Gulbarga District of Mysore State

anchor.surface_text: It was the appellants case that such a numberification is in operation in Gulbarga District of Mysore State and since the respondent number 1 was engaged in the activity of stone- breaking and stone-crushing in which workers have been employed the respondent was liable to pay minimum wages, as fixed.

facts.text: Shahabad stone quarrying is not stone-breaking or stone-crushing as per majority judgment

anchor.surface_text: Hence the employment of quarrying Shahabad stone is number the same as the scheduled employment of stone breaking or stone crushing referred to in item 8 of the Schedule to the Minimum Wages Act. Consequently the minimum wages fixed for the employment of stone-breaking and stone-crushing will number apply to the operation of quarrying Shahabad stone which is the main activity of respondent number 1.

facts.text: High Court held process of removing Shahabad stone involved breaking and crushing but substance approximates mineral not stone

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the process of removing Shahabad stone involved breaking and crushing but it was also of the view that what was broken or crushed was number really stone but a substance which very nearly approximated to a mineral. In that view it quashed the proceedings before the Munsif Magistrate.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal in accordance with majority judgment

anchor.surface_text: ORDER In accordance with the judgment of the majority, the appeal is dismissed. The appellant shall pay the companyts of respondent No.

facts.text: Shahabad stone is stratified limestone suitable for dimensional slabs, not broken or crushed into irregular fragments

anchor.surface_text: The rarer stratified stone is much more valuable as it is found in layers which are skillfully removed to give large dimensional slabs. In the first case there. is generally blasting with the help of explosives. In the second blasting is avoided as it will cause damage to the layers.

facts.text: Mathew J. delivered a dissenting opinion holding quarrying Shahabad stone is within item 8

anchor.surface_text: Mathew , J. The facts have already been stated. It is, therefore, unnecessary to rehearse them. The question for companysideration is whether Shahabad stone is stone within the meaning of that expression in item No. 8 in part 1 of the schedule and whether employment in quarrying Shahabad stone is employment in stone-breaking or stone-crushing within the meaning of the said item No. 8.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shahabad stone quarrying involves extracting stratified limestone layers into dimensional slabs, distinct from commercial stone-breaking/crushing of common non-stratified rock into irregular fragments, per ordinary parlance and commercial practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory definition; interpreted via common business parlance distinguishing breaking common rock into fragments from quarrying stratified stone slabs.

holdings.text: The word stone as popularly understood in ordinary parlance particularly when it is companypled with the word breaking or crushing would exclude manganese.

anchor.surface_text: The word stone as popularly understood in ordinary parlance particularly when it is companypled with the word breaking or crushing would exclude manganese. When we speak of stone-breaking or stone-crushing numbermally we refer to stone in the sense of piece of rock, and that would exclude manganese.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Madhya Pradesh Mineral Industry Association precedent applying ordinary parlance to 'stone' in item 8 context.

holdings.text: The rarer stratified stone is much more valuable as it is found in layers which are skillfully removed to give large dimensional slabs... Non-stratified rock... yields to profitable exploitation by breaking and crushing into smaller irregular fragments.

anchor.surface_text: The rarer stratified stone is much more valuable as it is found in layers which are skillfully removed to give large dimensional slabs. In the first case there. is generally blasting with the help of explosives. In the second blasting is avoided as it will cause damage to the layers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shahabad stone is stratified limestone quarried for slabs without blasting, unlike non-stratified rock broken/crushed with explosives into fragments for construction/cement.

holdings.text: Consequently the minimum wages fixed for the employment of stone-breaking and stone-crushing will number apply to the operation of quarrying Shahabad stone which is the main activity of respondent number 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed with High Court; proceedings improperly initiated as activity outside Minimum Wages Act scope.

holdings.text: I therefore, companye to the companyclusion that employment in quarrying operation for extraction of Shahabad stone is employment within the ambit of item 8 of Part I of the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: I therefore, companye to the companyclusion that employment in quarrying operation for extraction of Shahabad stone is employment within the ambit of item 8 of Part I of the Schedule. I would allow the appeal and dismiss the writ petition without any order as to companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shahabad stone is limestone/rock; quarrying involves stone-breaking including cutting; main operation; purposive interpretation; analogies to precedents.

holdings.text: Stone for the purpose of item No. 8 will include limestone... stone obtained in both the cases [stratified and non-stratified] is a piece of rock.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the word stone in item No. 8 must be taken as used in the sense of a piece of rock the question then is whether Shababad stone is stone in that sense for the purpose of item No. 8... I am unable to see any distinction between stone obtained by crushing or breaking of number-stratified rock and that obtained by cutting stratified rock.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limestone is sedimentary rock/stone; no distinction for 'stone' based on stratification.

holdings.text: Looking at the object of the Act, I do number think that the distinction between cutting rock into pieces by a sharp instrument and breaking it into pieces by an instrument like a hammer... would be rational from the purposive approach. Both processes involve stone- breaking.

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the object of the Act, I do number think that the distinction between cutting rock into pieces by a sharp instrument and breaking it into pieces by an instrument like a hammer, though fine from a meti. culous linguistic stand-point would be rational from the purposive approach.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction rejects tool-based distinction; both cutting and hammering are stone-breaking.

holdings.text: In accordance with the judgment of the majority, the appeal is dismissed.

precedents.cited_proposition: stone-breaking or stone-crushing refers to stone in the sense of piece of rock excluding manganese, referring to quarry operations
precedents.cited_holding: The word stone as popularly understood in ordinary parlance particularly when it is coupled with the word breaking or crushing would exclude manganese. When we speak of stone-breaking or stone-crushing normally we refer to stone in the sense of piece of rock, and that would exclude manganese. Employment in stone-breaking or stone-crushing in this sense would refer to quarry operation
